item.title: George Floyd's funeral hears calls for racial justice
item.description: The US black man's killing by a white police officer in Minneapolis caused global outrage.

item.title: Robert Milligan: Slave trader statue removed from outside London museum
item.description: The Canal and River Trust says the Robert Milligan statue's removal "recognises community wishes" .

item.title: Coronavirus: All primary pupils no longer going back to school
item.description: The reopening of primary school for all year groups in England has been ditched by the government.

item.title: Coronavirus: Zoos and safari parks set to reopen from 15 June - PM
item.description: Boris Johnson is due to announce the move will be subject to distancing measures being in place.

item.title: Babylon Health admits GP app suffered a data breach
item.description: The video call app allowed some patients to see recordings of others' sessions with medics.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: New inquiry 'could be dropped' without clues from public
item.description: More information is needed from the public to take the new suspect to court, German prosecutors say.

item.title: Frankie Macritchie dog attack death: Mum Tawnee Willis jailed
item.description: Frankie Macritchie, nine, was left alone in a caravan with the "extremely powerful" dog, a court hears.

item.title: Russian Arctic oil spill pollutes big lake near Norilsk
item.description: There is a risk that tonnes of diesel oil could drift from the lake to the Arctic Ocean.

item.title: Prince Philip: Photo with Queen to mark Duke of Edinburgh's 99th birthday
item.description: The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh are shown at Windsor Castle, where they are staying during lockdown.

item.title: Little Britain pulled from iPlayer and Netflix because 'times have changed'
item.description: The corporation says "times have changed" since the sketch show first aired.

item.title: Munroe Bergdorf: Model rejoins L'Oreal after racism row
item.description: The transgender model was dropped by the brand in 2017 after she posted comments about racism.

item.title: Coronavirus: RNLI expanding beach lifeguard cover
item.description: There would usually be lifeguard patrols on 240 beaches across the UK and Channel Islands.

item.title: Boy, 6, runs the distance of a marathon in costumes 'for the superheroes of the NHS'
item.description: A six-year-old boy from Plymouth has run a mile a day 26 times to raise money for the NHS.

item.title: George Floyd: Black Lives Matter protests go global
item.description: People in New Zealand, Canada, London and Germany are protesting in support of Black Lives Matter.

item.title: Little Mix's Leigh-Anne Pinnock 'doesn't care' about losing racist fans
item.description: Leigh-Anne Pinnock says she will continue to speak about her experiences of racism, regardless.

item.title: Coronavirus: The Sikh community kitchen feeding thousands
item.description: One of the UK's largest Sikh temples has reinvented itself as an emergency food operation.

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: The shortlist and category winners for the 2020 Sony World Photography Awards Open competition.

item.title: Jamelia: 'It's covert racism that's so damaging'
item.description: Singer Jamelia speaks out after Boris Johnson's claim that the UK has made "huge strides" in tackling racism.

item.title: Coronavirus: Transiting Europe's eerily quiet airports
item.description: BBC Europe correspondent Jean Mackenzie has documented her flight back to the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Duchess makes virtual visit to addiction centre
item.description: Catherine spoke to recent residents who are receiving support online during the lockdown.

item.title: Friends co-creator Marta Kauffman says she 'didn't do enough' for diversity
item.description: Marta Kauffman says she would now make "very different decisions" about the hit sitcom.

item.title: Climate Basics: CO2 explained
item.description: CO2 is at the heart of our changing climate. Here's why.

item.title: If it ain't broke: You share your oldest working gadgets
item.description: People share the oldest gadgets they still use, via social media.

item.title: Fitzwilliam Museum masterpieces reimagined with face masks
item.description: The Fitzwilliam creates "a unique perspective on our current lives through the art we know and love".

item.title: Why this doctor's phone is her coronavirus helpline
item.description: Junior doctor Lisa Linpower describes how vital her phone has been during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: George Floyd death: 'We have a pandemic of black people dying every day'
item.description: Two young organisers of the weekend's protests tell BBC theirs is the generation to bring real change.

item.title: The only disease right now is racism, says Sterling
item.description: England forward Raheem Sterling backs protests taking place across the UK, saying "the only disease right now is the racism that we are fighting".

item.title: Coronavirus: 'We started going out in the first week of lockdown'
item.description: Sarah and Tom began a relationship in lockdown - they're now sharing bottles of sanitizer instead of wine.

item.title: Martin Gugino: Donald Trump's police scanner tweet fact-checked
item.description: President Trump claimed a man was trying to "black out" police equipment, but is this possible?

item.title: The black British history you may not know about
item.description: From the black Britons in Roman times, to Henry VIII's trumpeter and our very own bus boycott.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: 'Why we stood up for George Floyd in the UK'
item.description: Three people talk about why they decided to protest in UK towns following the death of George Floyd.

item.title: School still out for most pupils but what do parents think?
item.description: While some parents are keen for schools to reopen, others are concerned about safety.

item.title: George Floyd death: Why US protests are so powerful this time
item.description: There have been many Black Lives Matter protests before, but things seem different this time. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: How Covid-19 has changed the 'big fat Indian wedding'
item.description: Can simple intimate ceremonies be the new normal in a country obsessed with lavish weddings?

item.title: How backpacking towns are coping after being left empty by coronavirus
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has "decimated" backpacker towns like Queenstown, Cusco and Arugam Bay.

item.title: The treasure trove hidden in discarded computers
item.description: Recycled rare earth magnets are one solution to the rising demand for minerals used in our tech.

item.title: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
item.description: Have the long hours of isolation during coronavirus lockdown led people to reflect on failed relationships?

item.title: Telling my brother's Windrush scandal story as a TV drama
item.description: The TV drama Sitting in Limbo follows Anthony Bryan, who was almost deported after 50 years in the UK.

item.title: Arriving passengers: 'Quarantine is like a staycation'
item.description: Passengers arriving at Stansted Airport speak about how the new quarantine rules have affected them.

item.title: EFL: Threat of clubs going bust because of coronavirus not gone away - Rick Parry
item.description: The threat of clubs going bust because of the financial impact of Covid-19 has not gone away, says Football League chairman Rick Parry.

item.title: England's Genge defends tearing down of Bristol slave trader statue
item.description: Bristol-born England rugby international Ellis Genge says the tearing down of the Edward Colston statue was "warranted".

item.title: Southgate 'tremendously proud' of campaigning England players
item.description: Gareth Southgate says he is "tremendously proud" of how England players have spoken out on racism and campaigned for charity in recent months.

item.title: Stoke manager O'Neill tests positive for Covid-19
item.description: Stoke City manager Michael O'Neill tests positive for Covid-19 after the latest round of testing on Monday and a planned practice match against Manchester United is cancelled.

item.title: Women's football 'pushed aside' - England's record goalscorer Smith
item.description: Ex-England striker Kelly Smith says women's football has been "pushed aside" after the season was brought to an early end.

item.title: League One & League Two clubs vote to end seasons early
item.description: The League One and League Two seasons are both ended early after a formal vote by clubs on Tuesday.

item.title: PGA Tour to honour Floyd with moment's silence on each round in Texas
item.description: A minute's silence will be held during each round of this week's PGA Tour event in Texas to honour George Floyd, a black American who died after a white police officer knelt on his neck.

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.title: Coronavirus: Will UK universities open in September?
item.description: Will students have online or face-to-face learning this autumn, and will they still have to pay full fees?

item.title: Coronavirus and face coverings: the correct way to wear them
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are going back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England next week, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the chance of going on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus: Saffron Walden dentist shows new appointment routine
item.description: Join us on a walk through a dental surgery to show what you might face at your next appointment.

item.title: Can I avoid quarantine by flying via Ireland?
item.description: Questions about the new quarantine regulations, and other coronavirus topics

item.title: Coronavirus: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why are international comparisons difficult?
item.description: Should you be comparing Covid-19 statistics between countries?

item.title: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are to become compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: You can now meet more people and play certain non-contact sports in the UK - but what are they?

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: Five key questions about energy after Covid-19
item.description: The pandemic has seen CO2 emissions fall - but will these changes be permanent?

item.title: Homes to be heated by warm water from flooded mines
item.description: Can abandoned British coal mines help tackle the climate crisis?

item.title: Demands grow for 'green industrial revolution'
item.description: Campaigners demand the government prioritises the environment in any post-Covid-19 stimulus package.

item.title: Make Covid-19 recovery green, say business leaders
item.description: Well-known firms such as Asda and Lloyds Bank are urging ministers to prioritise the environment.

item.title: What is climate change? A really simple guide
item.description: BBC News looks at what we know and don't know about the Earth's changing climate.

item.title: Record drop in energy investment, warns International Energy Agency
item.description: The pandemic has caused a record fall in energy investment and will likely lead to more pollution.

item.title: Climate change: What do all the terms mean?
item.description: Use our translator tool to find out what all the scientific terms used to discuss climate change actually mean.

item.title: From the archives: How do you decide when a statue must fall?
item.description: We name buildings after people, or put up statues to them, because we respect them. But what if we discover they did wrong?
